FAQ.question: What is the purpose of Patta / Chitta?
FAQ.answer: Patta records ownership and revenue details, while Chitta provides land classification such as wet, dry, or specific usage categories.

FAQ.question: Why is Land Type required to fetch Patta / Chitta?
FAQ.answer: Classification (wet/dry/urban/agricultural) helps fetch the correct record from revenue systems, especially when multiple entries exist for the same survey number.

FAQ.question: Does Patta / Chitta confirm legal ownership?
FAQ.answer: It supports ownership claims but final legal proof remains the registered Sale Deed and EC history.

FAQ.question: Does Patta / Chitta show subdivision details?
FAQ.answer: Yes. Chitta reflects sub-division mapping when land is split or partially transferred.

FAQ.question: Why is the ownerâ€™s contact number required?
FAQ.answer: It helps fetch linked records and verify identity in portals where OTP or registered contact validation is required.

FAQ.question: Can Patta / Chitta show government or assigned land?
FAQ.answer: It may indicate classification, but restricted or prohibited status requires a separate verification report.

FAQ.question: Does Patta / Chitta show building approval or layout permissions?
FAQ.answer: No. It only shows land classification; planning approvals must be checked through CMDA/DTCP or municipal authorities.

FAQ.question: Will Patta update automatically after property registration?
FAQ.answer: No. Mutation must be applied separately after registration to update Patta records.

FAQ.question: Can Patta exist without a Sale Deed?
FAQ.answer: Yes, in inheritance cases, government-allotted land, or ancestral holdings without registered transactions.

FAQ.question: Is data from JaaGa authentic?
FAQ.answer: Yes. All records are retrieved directly from government revenue portals without alterations.
